nodes.text: A systematic empirical comparison of typical feature selection methods can provide a practical guideline to choose appropriate methods and thereby improve text classification performance
This paper conducts a systematic comparison of twenty typical feature selection methods for text classification

The paper introduces and discusses typical supervised and unsupervised feature selection methods and their formulas (e.g., IG, ECE, MI variants, GI, IGI, CHI variants, OR variants, MOR, MC-OR, DF, TF, MM, AMGM, TV, MAD, TVQ)

Experimental setup: four benchmark datasets from UCI (CARR, COMD, IMDB, KDCN), decision tree classifier, classification accuracy as metric, 10-fold cross validation, experiments vary number of selected terms

Supervised feature selection methods evaluated include information gain (IG), expected cross entropy (ECE), mutual information (MI) avg and max, Gini index (GI), improved Gini index (IGI), chi-square (CHI) variants, odds ratio (OR) variants, MOR and MC-OR

Unsupervised feature selection methods evaluated include document frequency (DF), term frequency (TF), mean-median (MM), arithmetic mean/geometric mean (AMGM), term variance (TV), mean absolute difference (MAD), term variance quality (TVQ)
Experimental result: MOR and MC-OR achieve the best classification accuracies overall, with no significant difference between them; IGI ranks immediately after them (ranking MOR = MC-OR > IGI)
Experimental result: Unsupervised methods TV, TVQ, TF and DF achieve relatively good performance and higher efficiency; TVQ performs best among methods on the IMDB dataset

Experimental result: CHI variants perform relatively well with similar accuracies; ECE performs well generally but poorly when the number of selected terms is small; IG, GI and MI perform worst among evaluated methods; EOR and WOR follow IG/GI/MI

Claim: MOR and MC-OR are recommended when classification accuracy is the primary goal, but their formulas are relatively complex and require computing term-class distributions, increasing computational cost
Claim: IGI is an ideal candidate balancing strong performance and simpler implementation compared with MOR and MC-OR

Conclusion: Selection of feature selection method should trade off classification accuracy and computational efficiency; use supervised methods like MOR/MC-OR/IGI for best accuracy and unsupervised methods like TV/TVQ/TF/DF when efficiency is prioritized
